path: /posts/2020 is the year of embracing code

markdownRemark.html:
2020 is the year of embracing code.

My first work experience in high school was learning some Java interning over the summer at a small software company.

I learned a lot but decided code wasn’t for me.

I felt much more at home making physical stuff so I went to study mechanical engineering instead. I learned, I built things, and I got a masters degree along the way.

Code did keep pulling me back every now and then, while interning for cummins turbo technologies I wrote data analysis scripts in Python as one of the few people in my department who could to predict how damaged they get in use.

After my masters degree I went into programme (project) management at Aston Martin launching new models.

I spent 2 years at Aston Martin and during that time I started taking tutorials on freecodecamp.com to learn fullstack javascript development as a hobby.

I found a https://news.ycombinator.com/ “who’s hiring?” thread for a programming job, completed a few take home tests and some team-fit calls and now I work for an American start up company that is fully remote!

Since September I’ve been writing Javascript everyday at home!

What I’m learning this year

  • ReactJS - which incidentally is how this blog is made.
  • Redux
  • Typescript
  • Redux.
  • Typescript.
  • Css / Sass.
  • I can use css frameworks like bootstrap, bulma, and tailwindCSS.
  • I am also able to write python for engineering and web applications.

What I’m reading in January

I finished reading The Checklist Manifesto by Atul Gawande

This book is all about how to get things right in a world where our work is increasingly complex.

It follows the path of Atul, a leading surgeon, on his study of checklists used by pilots and other professions and how their use in operating theaters around the world dramatically lowered surgery complications and deaths.

Atul gives us an entertaining story but also the introspection on how checklists can help anyones job become less error prone and improve the quality and safety checks in whatever we might happen to be doing.

Link to the book on wiki
